contentrichtext.text: {{for|the television show|Ni Hao, Kai-lan}} {{no footnotes|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox Cultivar | name = Kai-lan | image = Gailan.jpg | image_width = 240px | image_caption = Kai-lan | species = ''[[Brassica oleracea]]'' | group = Alboglabra Group | origin = unknown | subdivision = unknown }} {{Chinese |t=[[wikt:芥蘭|芥蘭]] |s=[[wikt:芥兰|芥兰]] |p=gàilán, jièlán |y=gaai<sup>3</sup> laan<sup>4</sup> |poj=keh-nâ |wuu=kei lei ([ge.le]) |l="mustard orchid" |my=ကုက်လန် |tha=[[wikt:ผักคะน้า|ผักคะน้า]] (''phak khana'') |<!-- unreferenced characters that do not correspond to quoc ngu reading hantu=芥蘭--> |qn=''[[wikt:cải làn|cải làn]]'' or ''[[wikt:cải rổ|cải rổ]]''}} '''Kai-lan''' (also written as '''gai-lan''') is the Cantonese name for a vegetable that is also known as '''Chinese broccoli'''. It is a [[leaf vegetable]] featuring thick, flat, glossy blue-green leaves with thick stems and a small number of tiny, almost vestigial flower heads similar to those of [[broccoli]]. Broccoli and kai-lan belong to the same species ''[[Brassica oleracea]]'', but kai-lan is in the group ''alboglabra'' [Latin albus+glabrus white and hairless]. Its flavor is very similar to that of broccoli, but slightly more bitter. It is also noticeably stronger. [[Broccolini]] is a hybrid between broccoli and kai-lan, produced by Mann Packing Company, Inc. ''Kai-lan'' is eaten widely in [[Chinese cuisine]], and especially in [[Cantonese cuisine]]. Common preparations include kai-lan [[stir frying|stir-fried]] with [[ginger]] and [[garlic]], and [[boiling|boiled]] or steamed and served with [[oyster sauce]]. It is also common in [[Vietnamese cuisine]], [[Cuisine of Burma|Myanmar]] (as ကိုက်လန်) and [[Thai cuisine]]. ''Kai-lan'' can be sown in late summer for early-winter harvesting. Seedlings planted in autumn will last all winter.{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}} ==Gallery== <center> <gallery widths=200> File:baby kailan chinese.jpg|Baby kai-lan served [[Cantonese cuisine|Cantonese style]] File:Phat khana mu krop.jpg|Phak khana mu krop: Thai style fried Chinese broccoli with crispy [[pork]] </gallery> </center> ==See also== *[[Bok choy]] *[[Kale]] *[[Rapeseed]] *[[Rapini]] ==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite web | title=Chinese Kale (Gai Lan, Chinese Broccoli) | url=http://www.evergreenseeds.com/chinkalgail.html | publisher=Evergreen Seeds | date= | accessdate=6 February 2013}} {{commonscat|Brassica oleracea var. alboglabra}} {{Cantonese cuisine}} {{Brassica oleracea}} [[Category:Leaf vegetables]] [[Category:Brassica oleracea]] [[Category:Cantonese cuisine]] [[Category:Hong Kong cuisine]] [[Category:Burmese cuisine]]
